Abstract: Elliot L Richardson, who refused Pres Richard M Nixon's order to fire special Watergate prosecutor, dies at age of 79; he served in wide variety of positions in both Massachusetts and in federal government, but he will be best remembered as Nixon's attorney general, who resigned rather than dismiss Archibald M Cox; after Richardson resigned, his second-in-command, William D Ruckelshaus, was fired after also refusing to fire Cox; those events became known as Saturday Night Massacre; Robert H Bork, then solicitor general, accepted assignment and fired Cox; photos (M)

LeadParagraph: Elliot L. Richardson, the archetype of the cultivated New England Brahmin who served in an astonishingly broad range of high public positions, and who was best known for his refusal during Watergate to obey President Richard M. Nixon's order to fire a special prosecutor, died yesterday in his native Massachusetts. He was 79.

Headline.Main: Elliot Richardson Dies at 79; Stood Up to Nixon and Resigned In 'Saturday Night Massacre'
